results.title: Fire Woman and Tristan's Ascension: Bill Viola installation and interviews
results.brief_description:
This film captures the installation of the large projection screen and associated audio visual equipment needed to showcase Bill Viola’s works, ‘Fire Woman’ & ‘Tristan’s Ascension’. The exhibition took place at St Carthage’s Catholic Church in Parkville and the film features a short introduction by John Kaldor and interviews with Bill Viola and Father Michael Elligate.

Bill Viola has been instrumental in the establishment of video as a vital form of contemporary art. For over 40 years he has created videotapes, architectural video installations, sound environments, electronic music performances, flat panel video pieces and works for television broadcast. His video installations, total environments that envelop the viewer in image and sound, employ state-of-the-art technologies and are distinguished by their precision and direct simplicity.

results.title: Fire Woman and Tristan's Ascension: Bill Viola opening night
results.brief_description:
On October 6th 2010, Father Michael Elligate of St Carthage’s Catholic Church in Parkville introduced John Kaldor and Bill Viola, formally launching the exhibition. Presented by ACMI along with Melbourne International Arts Festival and Kaldor Public Art Projects, the exhibition gave Melbourne audiences a unique chance to experience the work of one of the world’s more influential and important artists.

John Kaldor speaks of his admiration for Bill Viola’s work, and his contemporary use of the moving image, Bill in turn talks about his work, processes and inspirations.

Bill Viola has been instrumental in the establishment of video as a vital form of contemporary art. For over 40 years he has created videotapes, architectural video installations, sound environments, electronic music performances, flat panel video pieces and works for television broadcast. His video installations - total environments that envelop the viewer in image and sound - employ state-of-the-art technologies and are distinguished by their precision and direct simplicity.

results.title: In conversation with Bill Viola: Melbourne International Arts Festival 2010
results.brief_description:
In October 2010, renowned American artist Bill Viola travelled to Melbourne to install two exhibitions of his work : ‘The Raft’ at ACMI and ‘Fire Woman and Tristan’s Ascension’ at St Carthage’s Catholic Church in Parkville. Presented by ACMI along with Melbourne International Arts Festival and Kaldor Public Art Projects, these two exhibitions gave Melbourne audiences a unique chance to experience the work of one of the world’s more influential and important artists.

Viola has been instrumental in the establishment of video as a vital form of contemporary art. For over 40 years he has created videotapes, architectural video installations, sound environments, electronic music performances, flat panel video pieces and works for television broadcast. His video installations – total environments that envelop the viewer in image and sound – employ state-of-the-art technologies and are distinguished by their precision and direct simplicity.

In this film Bill Viola is in conversation with Rachel Kohn, Producer and Presenter of ‘The Spirit of things’ and ‘The Ark’ on Radio National.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Mount Alexander
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Shire of Mount Alexander is located in the central region of Victoria. These nine stories cover the towns Castlemaine, Newstead and Maldon. Locals from the region discuss living in the country, the reasons for choosing to living in these towns and the community spirit so crucial to the region’s survival.

results.creator_credit_for_label: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Moyne
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine stories that embrace the spirit of three towns in the Moyne region in Victoria. Through interviews with the locals and footage of the region and various events, this compilation encapsulates life in Victorian towns today, the reasons for choosing the rural life over the city, activities, concerns and the things that bind these small communities together. Filmed as part of ‘ACMI in the regions’.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from South Gippsland
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Twelve stories, set in three different towns situated in the South Gippsland region. Comprises of interviews and stories about the townspeople of Meeniyan, Bena, Loch, Poowong, Nyora, Mirboo North and Mount Best. It looks at their past, daily lives and the things that bind these small communities together.

results.title: The Milky way = Dairy farming in Maffra
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This film showcases farming in the Maffra region and features six farmers who are leading the way in innovation and new farming technologies. Alan Clyne and his son Allister together with Robert White and John White are involved in the Herd Improvement initiative. Graeme Anderson and his son Ross are making the most of new irrigation techniques. Max Warren introduces his Robotic Dairy, the first ever to be used in Australia.
results.title_for_label: The Milky way = Dairy farming in Maffra

Graeme Anderson and his son Ross are making the most of new irrigation techniques. Max Warren introduces his Robotic Dairy, the first ever to be used in Australia.

results.title: Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This film focuses on the young people of Maffra. Eight students from Maffra Secondary College were interviewed, representing all the year levels, and asked to talk about life in a regional town, their hopes for the future and issues that affect them and their world.
The end result is a portrait of young rural Victorians who are thoughtful and engaging, with concerns about the environment, world politics and the survival of small towns.

results.title: Welcome to Maffra
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This film starts with Darren McCubbin, the Mayor of the Wellington Shire, welcoming the audience to Maffra. Darren explains that we are about to visit some of the places and meet some of the people that make Maffra a unique place to live. The film features the Geoff Webster Centre, the Gippsland Vehicle Collection, the Maffra Gymnastics Club, the George Gray Centre, Wallaby Rise Restaurant, Cambrai Backpacker Hostel and Jenny McDavitt an Alpaca farmer and Ferial Zikerman who is now internationally known for her Maffra Cheese.
results.description: This film starts with Darren McCubbin, the Mayor of the Wellington Shire, welcoming the audience to Maffra.
